abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Third National
            Agricultural Extension Project in India are as follows:
            overall outcome of the project are rated partially
            satisfactory, and the performance of the Bank the Borrower
            was also rated satisfactory. Lessons learned from the
            project are: 1) lack of staff mobility is still constraining
            operations of field extension staff. Inadequate advantage
            was taken by the state governments of finance and provide
            policy support for the proposed personal loans scheme for
            staff to purchase private vehicles for public use; 2) there
            is a need to more fully exploit the use of cost effective
            media materials (radio, television and video and printed
            materials) and modern communication systems to enhance
            dissemination of technical information); and 3) the
            inclusion of a component to finance Special Sub-Projects
            (SSPs) for the Government of India (GOI) to undertake
            regular reviews and special studies, provided flexibility in
            project design to allow the GOI to obtain a national
            perspective on extension development in India. However,
            insufficient use was made of this information by state
            Government of Assam (DOAs) to rectify specific constraints
            and identified weaknesses in extension development.
